title: Publications & Talks
text:
Conferences

Decomposing Uncertainty in Projected Changes in Extreme Precipitation: A Dynamic and Thermodynamic Perspective
23 May 2025
Yeosu, South Korea ‚Äì Korea Water Resources Association Annual Conference
 I presented research on the exploration of uncertainty in extreme precipitation and its two components: thermodynamic and dynamic processes, as well as their associated uncertainties. The study decomposes total projection uncertainty into three well-known sources in climate science: model structure, emission scenarios, and internal variability.
You can find my presentation here. 


Decomposing uncertainty in extreme precipitation scaling rates for future climate projection
10 May 2024
Jeju, South Korea ‚Äì Korea Water Resources Association Annual Conference
 Extreme precipitation is strongly linked to temperature, as warmer conditions allow the atmosphere to hold more moisture, enhancing the potential for intense rainfall. However, this relationship is found to be highly uncertain. In this talk, I explored the uncertainty surrounding the projected increase rates of extreme precipitation under future climate scenarios.
I was selected as the Oral Best Presentation Winner for the international session.
You can find my presentation here.

Introduction to Databases ‚Äì Coursera & Meta
A foundational course from Meta introducing core database concepts and SQL for data querying and management.

A hands-on course covering data visualization on Tableau. Starting from data preparation to the concept of data visualization to get the best insights.

A practical course focused on using SQL to query databases, designed specifically for data science workflows with Python.



  






Python and Pandas for Data Engineering ‚Äì Coursera & Duke University
A hands-on course focusing on data engineering tools using Python and Pandas. Includes project environment setup, working with data structures, and essential development tools.

title: Sothearith Min
text:
About me!
I‚Äôm a climate scientist based in South Korea. My research interests include extreme rainfall projections and their uncertainties.
I analyze large-scale climate datasets using Python, with a strong focus on uncovering insights from geospatial data. I‚Äôm passionate about data visualization and love bringing climate stories to life through compelling maps and visual narratives. I enjoy translating complex datasets into intuitive visuals that inform and inspire.
I completed my Bachelor‚Äôs degree in Statistics at Burapha University, Thailand. I then pursued a Master‚Äôs degree at Kongju National University in South Korea, with the financial support of Professor Ahn Kuk-Hyun.
My research focuses on the uncertainty of climate projections related to extreme events, particularly extreme rainfall, which plays a critical role in disasters such as floods. I have recently defended my thesis, and you can view my defense slides here.
